current_fact.fact_text: On this day in World War II, 1941, the British destroyer HMS Greyhound and other escorts of convoy AS‑12 sank the Italian submarine Neghelli near the Greek island of Falkonera. The engagement highlighted the deadly cat‑and‑mouse struggle beneath the waves in the Mediterranean.

episode.title: Morning Drops #33 - Immerse
episode.description: An analogy between diving, one of Gaia's great passions, and the act of immersing in life itself. A reflection on what happens when we go below the surface: when we let ourselves be fully present. From moments of calm suspension to warm, rhythmic flow, the selection moves like water — fluid, organic, and alive. An invitation to slow down, listen deeper, and float.
songs: Pino D'Angiò - Un Po' d'Uva e un Liquore

current_fact.match_reason: A wartime drama in the underwater world pairs with an episode built on the metaphor of diving and immersion beneath the surface.

queue.fact_text: On January 19, 2024, Japan’s lunar lander SLIM attempted an ultra‑precise touchdown that, despite power issues after landing, still demonstrated formidable navigation and hazard‑avoidance capabilities. Its accuracy—aiming within a tiny patch of lunar terrain—pushes forward the idea of "pinpoint" landings for future missions.

episode.title: Morning Drops #19 - Wabi Sabi
episode.description: Wabi-sabi is a story about a handmade mug, a small mistake, and the idea that imperfection can be something to keep—not correct. In this Morning Drop, Gaia shares a moment that didn’t go to plan, and four tracks that echo the same spirit: rough takes, studio accidents, lo-fi textures, and quiet surprises. A soft, thoughtful selection moving between warm electronics, classic riffs, and raw edges.A reminder that not everything needs to be polished. Sometimes, it’s better that way.

queue.match_reason: A technically brilliant moon landing that ended with power problems mirrors the wabi‑sabi idea of beauty in ambitious attempts that don’t go perfectly.

queue.fact_text: On January 19, 1915, Georges Claude’s neon patent didn’t just create glowing signs; it also opened a new relationship between cities and night, turning darkness into a canvas for art and advertising. Neon’s soft hum and color became part of the modern urban soundscape and skyline.

episode.title: Morning Drops #12 - 80's Club
episode.description: Starting with a Monday evening in Munich — a few drinks, friends, and landing in an 80s dance party. From Donna Summer's hypnotic pulse, to Depeche Mode's bright synthpop, Ken Laszlo's Italo Disco romance, and Mylène Farmer's darker theatrical world. Four songs, four corners of the 80s — connected by the machines that changed how we dance.
songs: Depeche Mode - Just Can't Get Enough

queue.match_reason: Neon nightlife and 80s club culture are inseparable; glowing signs and synthpop machines together define the electronic night city.

queue.fact_text: On this day, 1853, when Il trovatore premiered, Verdi was already reimagining what opera could be—pushing drama and emotional intensity toward almost cinematic extremes. Its success helped cement opera as a mass entertainment that could travel far beyond elite salons.

episode.title: Morning Drops #01 - Timeless Legacy
episode.description: Gaia guides us through timeless music to start the morning with the right foot! The first episode of the Morning Drops series — classic sounds that never fade.
songs: Roberta Flack - Killing me softly with his song

queue.match_reason: A classic opera that has endured for generations pairs with an episode devoted to music with a "timeless legacy."

queue.fact_text: On January 19, 2007, Team N2i’s kite‑powered journey to the Antarctic pole of inaccessibility showed how simple tools—wind, skis, and stubbornness—can open some of Earth’s most remote places. Their approach highlighted a lower‑impact, almost playful way to explore extreme environments.

episode.title: Evening Flows #01 - Yasmin - Crescendo in the Medina
episode.description: The first Evening Flow episode comes from Yasmin. It starts deep in the medina, slow, mysterious, textured, and grows into a liberating dance across sub-Saharan landscapes. A journey through ambient soundscapes, Arabic melodies, Afro-Latin rhythms, and funky highlife grooves.
songs: David Visan & Carlos Campos - Crystal Heart
Evan Mars - Ya Zareef Al Tool
Dele Sosimi & Medlar - You No Fit Touch Am (Medlar Remix)

queue.match_reason: A journey driven by wind power and gradual buildup of effort fits with an evening mix that starts slow and crescendos into liberated movement across vast landscapes.

published.fact_text: On January 19, 2024, Japan's Smart Lander for Investigating Moon (SLIM) touched down on the lunar surface, making Japan the fifth nation to achieve a soft landing on the Moon. The mission aimed to demonstrate pinpoint landing technology—targeting an area just 100 meters across instead of the usual kilometers-wide ellipse.

episode.title: Morning Drops #03 - Space Shift
episode.description: Gaia invites you to shift your mindset with a simple yet powerful reflection: What if we saw emptiness not as a void but as space to create? An energising and feel-good selection of tracks, the perfect way to ease into your day and set the tone for the week ahead.
songs: Willy J Healey - Woke Up Smiling
The Strokes - You Only Live Once

published.match_reason: A literal shift into space pairs with an episode built around reimagining emptiness as creative space and forward momentum.

published.fact_text: In 2007, the four-man Team N2i reached Antarctica's pole of inaccessibility using only skis and kites, completing a 1,759 km journey without mechanical assistance. It was the first visit since 1965 and a rare example of using wind power to cross some of the coldest, most remote terrain on Earth.

episode.title: Morning Drops #40 - Diving With Orcas
episode.description: Yasmin's friend Caroline takes us beyond the polar circle, into the Arctic waters of Norway, where orcas and humpback whales gather each winter. A personal journey shaped by a quiet obsession with orcas, from Patagonia to the icy fjords of the north. The soundscape moves gently between cinematic swells and soft, rhythmic pulses — echoing the cold light of Arctic mornings and the grace of underwater encounters.

published.match_reason: Both stories unfold beyond the polar circle, blending human endurance with icy wilderness and a reflective, cinematic mood.

published.fact_text: On January 19, 1953, the "Lucy Goes to the Hospital" episode of I Love Lucy aired, showing Lucy giving birth on screen while Lucille Ball was pregnant in real life. Around 72% of all U.S. TV sets tuned in, making it one of the earliest mass shared television moments.

episode.title: Morning Drops #09 - Birthday Cake
episode.description: Today's breakfast comes with a sprinkle of stardust and a slice of birthday cake as we celebrate a pure and unique soul, Yasmin. On Sedna, we may not do years, but we sure know how to party!

published.match_reason: A record‑breaking TV birth aligns with an episode themed around celebration, milestones, and collective joy.

published.fact_text: In 1817, General José de San Martín led an army of about 5,400 soldiers across the Andes from Argentina, in one of history's most daring mountain crossings. This audacious maneuver paved the way for the liberation of Chile and later Peru from Spanish rule.

episode.title: Morning Drops #22 - Sicilians On The Dolomites
episode.description: Hosted by Yasmin, a musical journey inspired by the mountains. Joined by two special guests, exploring the tracks they've chosen, hearing the stories behind their picks, and discovering the personal memories each song brings to life — a blend of music, voices, and landscapes you can hear.
songs: Florian Pellissier Quintet - Coup de foudre à Thessalonique
Lucio Dalla & Francesco De Gregori - Ma come fanno i marinai

published.match_reason: A perilous military crossing of the Andes resonates with an episode built around mountain landscapes and the stories they inspire.

published.fact_text: On January 19, 1999, British Aerospace agreed to acquire the defence arm of the General Electric Company, creating BAE Systems later that year. The merger forged one of the world's largest defence, security, and aerospace companies, reshaping the European arms industry.

episode.title: Morning Drops #17 - Steel City
episode.description: Gaia takes us on a short trip through Sheffield's sounds — from electronic textures to raw guitars and sharp storytelling. Four tracks, one city, different edges of the same story.
songs: The Human League - The Sound Of The Crowd

published.match_reason: A story of heavy industry and high‑tech defense fits the metallic, industrial undertones and urban grit of the "Steel City" episode.

published.fact_text: In 1937, aviator and tycoon Howard Hughes set a transcontinental speed record by flying from Los Angeles to New York in just 7 hours, 28 minutes, and 25 seconds. His custom Lockheed aircraft turned the vast U.S. sky into a personal raceway, shrinking the continent for the jet age to come.

episode.title: Sedna FM #05 - On The Go - Zero Zero
episode.description: An energetic mix for when you're on the move. Zero Zero captures that feeling of starting fresh, moving forward, and embracing the journey. Perfect for travel, walks, or just getting things done.
songs: Grace Jones - Pull up to the bumper
Easy star all star - Soul love
James Brown - Talking loud and saying nothing (remix)

published.match_reason: A record‑breaking coast‑to‑coast flight mirrors the fast, kinetic, travel‑ready energy of "On The Go - Zero Zero."

published.fact_text: On January 19, 1996, the North Cape oil spill began when the tugboat Scandia caught fire and ran aground off Rhode Island, causing its barge to spill thousands of barrels of home heating oil. The slick contaminated fisheries and beaches, prompting large‑scale clean‑up and fresh scrutiny of coastal pollution.

episode.title: Morning Drops #23 - Morning Dubs
episode.description: Recorded while still processing Houghton Festival. One of the mornings there, waking up in the woods to a reggae DJ set — no phone signal, just trees, music, and loved ones. A slow selection of reggae, dub, and morning rhythms. Dubs instead of drops. Start your day slow — with space to breathe.
songs: The Gaylads - Joy in the Morning
King Tubby - King Tubby Meets the Rockers Uptown

published.match_reason: An environmental disaster at sea contrasts with a coastal, nature‑soaked dub morning; reggae’s long history of environmental and social awareness provides a contemplative counterpoint.

published.fact_text: On this day in 1861, Georgia seceded from the United States, joining several Southern states in breaking away and setting the stage for the American Civil War. The decision reflected deep tensions over slavery, states' rights, and the future shape of the young republic.

episode.title: Morning Drops #08 - (un)Boxing
episode.description: An episode about breaking free from expectations and labels. Music that helps us unbox ourselves and embrace who we truly are.
songs: Kendrick Lamar - The Blacker the Berry

published.match_reason: The secession crisis and its legacy of race and identity echo in a conscious‑rap episode focused on challenging labels and oppressive narratives.

published.fact_text: On January 19, 1993, both the Czech Republic and Slovakia were admitted to the United Nations, just weeks after peacefully dissolving Czechoslovakia. Their “Velvet Divorce” became a rare example of a state splitting into two nations without war.

episode.title: Morning Drops #11 - Mediterranean Boat
episode.description: Gaia invites you to embark on a musical voyage across the Mediterranean. Exploring music from different countries shared by people who call them home. A warm, sun-soaked journey through coastal sounds.
songs: Fabrizio De André - Crêuza de mä

published.match_reason: New countries joining a global community fits with an episode that sails between cultures and borders, celebrating coexistence of different homelands.

published.fact_text: In 1788, the second group of ships of the First Fleet arrived at Botany Bay, carrying convicts, marines, and supplies to establish a British penal colony in Australia. The fleet’s arrival marked the beginning of large‑scale European settlement and a profound, often devastating, transformation for Indigenous Australians.

episode.title: Morning Drops #31 - Sailing With Germans
episode.description: From the deck of a sailing boat, hosted by Yasmin and her special guests. A week at sea with six Germans, each with their own stories, songs, and ways of moving through the waves. From shared meals to unexpected laughter, from quiet resilience to sun-soaked joy — a collection of voices and tracks that reflect what it means to journey together.
songs: Ben Howard - Keep Your Head Up

published.match_reason: A historic voyage by sea connects with a modern story told from a sailboat deck; both mix ocean crossings with the complicated idea of 'new shores.'

published.fact_text: On January 19, 1871, during the Franco‑Prussian War, Prussian forces won the Battle of St. Quentin while the besieged city of Paris struggled to break free at Buzenval. These defeats helped seal France’s loss and laid foundations for German unification.

episode.title: Morning Drops #45 - It Can't Rain Forever
episode.description:
In this first broadcast of 2026, Gaia returns from the vivid landscapes of Morocco to open a space for reflection. This episode navigates the delicate transition between closing a significant chapter and stepping into the new year. It explores the concept of constancy amidst change, celebrating the grounding force of friendship and the creative sanctuary that is Sedna FM.

The musical selection mirrors this journey, moving from the orchestral depth of changing seasons into the golden warmth of psychedelic soul. It recalls memories of Swiss mountains and unexpected downpours, reminding us that shared optimism can weather any storm.

Take a moment to breathe in the new morning and listen deeply.

Mood: Reflective, Warm, Transitional, Hopeful
Music genre: Classic Rock, Psychedelic Soul, Pop Rock, Soft Rock

published.match_reason: A grim chapter of war and siege is paired with an episode about endurance through dark weather, offering a hopeful emotional counter‑narrative.

published.fact_text: In 1853, Giuseppe Verdi’s opera Il trovatore premiered in Rome, introducing audiences to a dark, melodramatic tale filled with mistaken identities, revenge, and one of opera’s most famous choruses, the "Anvil Chorus." Despite a complicated plot, its fiery music made it an instant success across Europe.

episode.title: Morning Drops #38 - History of Flamenco
episode.description: A special journey into the history of Flamenco, guided by Yasmin and her guest Almudena from Madrid, Spain. Exploring the roots and evolution of this emotionally raw and culturally rich tradition, from its early vocal origins and Andalusian influences, through its transformation on stage and screen, to its modern reinventions by iconic Spanish artists.
songs: La Niña de los Peines - Al Gurugú
Paco de Lucía - Entre dos aguas
Camarón de la Isla - La leyenda del tiempo

published.match_reason: A passionate 19th‑century Italian opera fits naturally with an episode exploring another highly dramatic, vocal, and theatrical art form: flamenco.

published.fact_text: On January 19, 1977, U.S. President Gerald Ford pardoned Iva Toguri D'Aquino, long accused of being "Tokyo Rose," a notorious World War II propagandist. Decades after her conviction, doubts about the fairness of her trial and the reliability of key witnesses led to this formal act of forgiveness.

episode.title: Sedna FM #06 - Alters of an Ego
episode.description: What if you could step outside yourself and become someone freer, bolder, or completely unexpected? Exploring the artistry of musicians who craft alter-egos and parallel realities to experiment with new dimensions of their identity. It's not about hiding who they are — it's about expanding who they can be.
songs: The Fireman - Strawberries Oceans Ships Forest

published.match_reason: A woman entangled in a disputed wartime persona connects with an episode about alter egos, public masks, and the complexities of identity.

published.fact_text: On this day in 1969, Czech student Jan Palach died after setting himself on fire three days earlier in Prague’s Wenceslas Square, protesting the Soviet-led invasion of Czechoslovakia. His funeral turned into a massive demonstration and his act became a powerful, tragic symbol of resistance.

episode.title: Morning Drops #44 - Residente
episode.description:
In this edition of Morning Drops, Yasmin navigates the complex geography of René Pérez Joglar, known to the world as Residente. His story is not just a musical evolution; it is a timeline marked by resistance, lyrical obsession, and a relentless search for identity.

From the gated streets of Trujillo Alto to the global stage, we explore how a restless mind transformed into the voice of a generation. The selection moves through the textures of his life: hearing the raw energy of his early rebellion, the sharp precision of his political critique, and finally, the fragile silence of his most personal confessions.

It is a study in duality. We witness the rapper who dismantles giants and the son who misses his mother. It is a soundscape that proves that sometimes, the loudest revolution happens inside.

Mood: Raw, Revolutionary, Introspective, Honest
Music genre: Latin Alternative, Hip Hop, Urban, World

published.match_reason: Palach’s ultimate act of protest fits with an episode centered on political resistance, dissent, and the personal cost of speaking out.

published.fact_text: On January 19, 1915, French engineer Georges Claude patented the neon discharge tube for advertising, turning electrified gas into glowing signage. Neon lights quickly transformed city nights into luminous galleries of color and typography.

episode.title: Morning Drops #05 - Electric Shock
episode.description: An energizing episode with electrifying sounds to wake you up and get you moving. High energy tracks that deliver a jolt of musical electricity to start your day.

published.match_reason: The birth of neon lighting pairs with an episode about electrifying sounds, both celebrating the aesthetic thrill of harnessed electricity.

published.fact_text: Also in 1915, German zeppelins carried out the first major aerial bombardment of civilian targets in Britain, striking Great Yarmouth and King’s Lynn. The raid killed at least 20 people and signaled a new, unsettling era where war could arrive silently from the sky.

episode.title: Sedna FM #01 - November Bomb
episode.description: The first Family & Friends radio episode from Yasmin Sarbaoui and Gaia Parolini. Where it all began — a life soundtrack that launched Sedna FM into the universe. Raw, heartfelt, and full of the energy that defines everything that followed.
songs: Canserbero - De la vida como pelicula, tragedia, comedia y ficcion

published.match_reason: The historic shock of aerial 'bombs' over cities is reframed through Sedna’s inaugural “November Bomb,” detonating with culture instead of explosives.

published.fact_text: On January 19, 1883, the first electric lighting system using overhead wires, developed by Thomas Edison, began service in Roselle, New Jersey. The small town became a testbed for a future where streets and homes could glow at the flick of a switch.

episode.title: Morning Drops #14 - Slow Planet
episode.description: A pause. A quiet return to slower rhythms, sparked by a live set under the summer sky. A moment to breathe and settle into the week.

published.match_reason: The quiet magic of the first electrically lit streets fits with a soft, glowing downtempo episode that feels like evening lights coming on.

published.fact_text: In 1829, Goethe’s Faust: The First Part of the Tragedy received its premiere performance, bringing to the stage his philosophical tale of a man who bargains with the devil for knowledge and experience. The story has since haunted literature, music, and film as a symbol of ambition and moral compromise.

episode.title: Sedna FM #03 - Beautiful as You Feel
episode.description: An episode about self-acceptance and inner beauty. Music that reminds us we are beautiful as we feel, embracing our authentic selves. Warm, uplifting sounds that celebrate individuality.
songs: The The - this is the day
DCTL - Deep Tannin f(eat Rafael Leafar)

published.match_reason: Faust’s dangerous pursuit of external fulfillment contrasts with an episode dedicated to inner beauty and self‑acceptance, offering a gentle antidote to his bargain.

published.fact_text: On January 19, 1764, Danish official Bolle Willum Luxdorph noted in his diary that Colonel Poulsen at Børglum Abbey had been severely injured by a mail bomb. This incident is considered one of the earliest recorded uses of a letter bomb—a deadly weapon disguised as ordinary correspondence.

episode.title: Morning Drops #27 - Nomophobia
episode.description: Yasmin reflects on what happened when she recently lost her phone and why it felt freeing. A dive into the psychology of our relationship with smartphones: from nomophobia (the fear of being without a phone), to digital burnout and cognitive overload, to the surprising benefits of boredom and the brain's default mode network. An invitation to rethink how we connect and disconnect.

published.match_reason: An early weaponized communication device is paired with an episode about modern communication overload—two eras wrestling with the power and danger of messages.

published.fact_text: On this day in World War II, 1941, the British destroyer HMS Greyhound and other escorts of convoy AS‑12 sank the Italian submarine Neghelli near the Greek island of Falkonera. The engagement highlighted the deadly cat‑and‑mouse struggle beneath the waves in the Mediterranean.

episode.description: An analogy between diving, one of Gaia's great passions, and the act of immersing in life itself. A reflection on what happens when we go below the surface: when we let ourselves be fully present. From moments of calm suspension to warm, rhythmic flow, the selection moves like water — fluid, organic, and alive. An invitation to slow down, listen deeper, and float.
